Award.AwardTitle: EAGER: Topological Optimization Methods for Designing Patient-Specific Large Craniofacial Segmental Bone Replacements

Division.LongName: Div Of Civil, Mechanical, & Manufact Inn

Award.AbstractNarration:
The objective of this Early-concept Grant for Exploratory Research (EAGER) project is to apply topological optimization methods to create feasible bone replacement forms for large segmental defects in craniofacial reconstruction. Restoring normal function and appearance after massive facial injuries due to blast or tumor removal with bone loss still remains an important unresolved problem in craniofacial reconstruction surgery. The current methods are heuristic in nature and ad hoc design of bone replacements is done by the operating surgeon at the time of surgery. Within a given space defined by the wound, bone replacements have to be designed to meet structural functions, to maintain permanently a specific three-dimensional shape, and to support soft tissues and prosthetic appliances. A multi-level topological optimized method will be applied and tailored to create new bone replacement forms that not only meet requirements for load-bearing, but also position tissue elements in the proper locations in space to support soft tissues and prosthetic appliances. The integration of the replacement forms in the deformity regions and validation of the feasibility of using the tailored craniofacial design shapes will be carried out.

The research project is a synergy of tissue engineering research, clinical surgery and computational mechanics. The adopted interdisciplinary approach combines the biomechanics of the mid-face with topological optimization techniques and finite element methods to build a technique for creating patient-specific topologically optimized bone replacement alternatives for craniofacial reconstruction. If successful, this research has the potential to improve the quality of life for individuals with large bone defects. The project can contribute to a global methodology for designing an optimized, patient-specific treatment protocol for tissue engineering with maximum treatment outcome in clinical applications in other anatomical defects. Elucidating the relationship between the structure and function of the craniofacial skeleton will enable advances in tissue engineering, prosthetics design and approaches to encourage prosthetics fixation, and design of engineered material systems. A multidisciplinary approach to study such problems will be exploited as a tool to develop undergrad and graduate student's critical thinking skills by using engineering concepts and tools to study biological and medical problems.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Craniofacial reconstruction of large segmental defect is a very complex surgical procedure. Restoration of these deformities when associated with blast or tumor removal is challenging. The trend in reconstruction surgery is to use bone grafts from the patient to restore the deformities by providing structural support for masticatory (biting) function and foundation for aesthetic considerations. These complicated replacement shapes vary from one patient to another. At present, the bone replacements are designed rather heuristically without a guarantee of structural function and form. A method based on multi-resolution topology optimization is developed that can be used to design patient-specific bone replacements. Few patient-specific cases were simulated. A parametric study is carried out to understand the sensitivity of different variables for the design framework. To test the feasibility mechanical testing is performed to see whether the implants can withstand the load. Using bone-like synthetic materials, both the skeleton and the implant are printed using 3D printing technology and fused together to mimic embedding the implant into the mid-face. A digital image correlation (DIC) strain measurement technique is used to capture the full field strain on the surface of the loaded skull model. The new bone replacement implants are optimized for masticatory loads to achieve maximum stiffness within minimum prescribed material. The mechanical testing shows that the design can withstand the masticatory forces and can be a viable solution.

Topology optimization has not been used in direct surgical care before. This research can change the face of reconstructive surgery by developing patient-specific solutions. The research showed that mimicking existing human craniofacial structure for reconstruction is not necessary and for each patient the optimum structure may be different based on patient’s specific medical and aesthetic needs.  Topology optimization shows good promise in designing complicated bone replacements and can create a new paradigm in one tissue surgery and regeneration. The adopted interdisciplinary approach combines the biomechanics of the mid-face with topological optimization techniques and finite element methods to build a model for creating patient-specific topologically optimized bone replacement alternatives for craniofacial reconstruction.

This research has the potential to improve the quality of life for individuals with large bone defects. This research can highly impact the global methodology for designing an optimized, patient-specific treatment protocol for tissue engineering with maximum treatment outcome in clinical applications for other anatomical defects as well.

This research provided graduate research opportunities to 2 female medical students, 1 female engineering graduate student and 1 undergraduate female engineering student. Also, another graduate student whose graduate studies was supported by this project submitted a master's thesis based on this research project. As part of outreach activity, the PIs conducted 'engineering design' themed science events in local elementary school to promote science, technology, engineering, and mathematics (STEM) among elementary school students.
